Award.AwardTitle: ST3: Research Collaborative Network on Information-driven Biomaterials
Award.AbstractNarration:
New concepts in the design of biomaterials have led to the moment in which biomaterials may be designed to make decisions. These decisions - including motility, replication, collective behavior, healing, and secretion - can be driven by molecular computational and decision-making networks embedded in materials. Increasing sophistication of both soft matter design and synthetic networks allow for the possibility of embedded synthetic networks in artificial cells and tissues that allow for intelligent information processing or self replication of materials. This award proposes a workshop to develop connections and ideas an international Research Collaborative Network (RCN) for the purposes of supporting collaborative work between U.S. and European scientists in the area of information-driven materials. The goal of this meeting will be to identify key areas of intersection between biomaterials synthesis and response and information encoding. The meeting follows upon a very successful Square Table that was held at NSF in the Fall of 2018 that identified many of the key scientific issues in this area. The focus of the meeting will be on fundamental issues in the design of materials and networks, informed by quantitative methods and computing, and to assess what can be achieved through state of the art materials design. Because the discipline is highly interdisciplinary, the meeting will bring together basic scientists from chemistry, physics, biology, engineering, and biomaterials science. Furthermore, this meeting will focus on how to activate an effective network of collaboration and identify areas of potential support at NSF for future programs on information-driven biomaterials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An international meeting of scholars from the U.S. and Europe was held in Philadelphia. PA on January 16 and 17, 2020 to discuss the field of Information Driven Biomaterials. The meeting was organized by Daniel A. Hammer (U. pennsylvania) and Tara L. Deans (U. Utah). The meeting was sponsored by the BMAT program of the Division of Materials Research. The meeting was the third in a series of round table discussions (SQIII) to understand the unique opportunities at the intersection of materials science and synthetic biology. The workshop contained individiual talks and three breakout sessions to identify the key issues in advancing science in this interdisciplinary area. The key focus areas of the meeting were:

1. How to make living materials that display features of life or integrate living components?

2. How do we build information processing into these materials, at the interface or deeply embedded within the materials?

3.  How do we make materials that can adapt to their environment?

4. What can we learn from extreme environments or stresses that can inform the design of new materials?

5. How do we couple sensing to actuation?

The meeting concluded with the identification of several "moon shot" ideas that might be worthy of support from NSF. These include developing responsive, multiplexed drug delivery systems; building orthogonal communicating systems; expanding the concept of information; using proteins as assembly tools; making reanimated synthetic cells including immune cells, building living building blocks for the design of hybrid materials architectures; using cells to modify the materials properties of environments; and using high throughout technologies and computational design for the development of novel materials.

A detailed report of recommendations was provided to NSF in June, 2020. The report concluded with specific recommendations on how the NSF might support ongoing research in this area, with particular focus on fostering interactions between the U.S. and Europe. These include student exchange programs, joint grants, and hubs where shared equipment might reside.

An issue of iScience in which review and white papers covering the topics of this meeting is contemplated.
